column5: short description

column4: FHIR Definition: \- | FHIR Comments: \-
column5: FHIR Path: Patient | FHIR Short: Information about an individual or animal receiving health care services

column4: FHIR Definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes. | FHIR Comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.id | FHIR Short: Logical id of this artifact

column4: FHIR Definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.meta | FHIR Short: Metadata about the resource

column4: FHIR Definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc. | FHIR Comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.implicitRules | FHIR Short: A set of rules under which this content was created
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: The base language in which the resource is written. | FHIR Comments: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.language | FHIR Short: Language of the resource content
column15: Arabic|Bulgarian|Bulgarian (Bulgaria)|Bengali|Czech|Czech (Czechia)|Bosnian|Bosnian (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|Danish|Danish (Denmark)|German|German (Austria)|German (Switzerland)|German (Germany)|Greek|Greek (Greece)|English|English (Australia)|English (Canada)|English (Great Britain)|English (India)|English (New Zealand)|English (Singapore)|English (United States)|Spanish|Spanish (Argentina)|Spanish (Spain)|Spanish (Uruguay)|Estonian|Estonian (Estonia)|Finnish|French|French (Belgium)|French (Switzerland)|French (France)|Finnish (Finland)|French (Canada)|Frisian|Frisian (Netherlands)|Hindi|Croatian|Croatian (Croatia)|Icelandic|Icelandic (Iceland)|Italian|Italian (Switzerland)|Italian (Italy)|Japanese|Korean|Lithuanian|Lithuanian (Lithuania)|Latvian|Latvian (Latvia)|Dutch|Dutch (Belgium)|Dutch (Netherlands)|Norwegian|Norwegian (Norway)|Punjabi|Polish|Polish (Poland)|Portuguese|Portuguese (Portugal)|Portuguese (Brazil)|Romanian|Romanian (Romania)|Russian|Russian (Russia)|Slovakian|Slovakian (Slovakia)|Slovenian|Slovenian (Slovenia)|Serbian|Serbian (Serbia)|Swedish|Swedish (Sweden)|Telugu|Chinese|Chinese (China)|Chinese (Hong Kong)|Chinese (Singapore)|Chinese (Taiwan)
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: preferred | FHIR Binding Description: A human language.

column4: FHIR Definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety. | FHIR Comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.text | FHIR Short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation

column4: FHIR Definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. | FHIR Comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contained | FHIR Short: Contained, inline Resources

column4: FHIR Definition: An Extension
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Short: Extension

column4:
FHIR Definition: Concepts classifying the person into a named category of humans sharing common history, traits, geographical origin or nationality.  The race codes used to represent these concepts are based upon the [CDC Race and Ethnicity Code Set Version 1.0](http://www.cdc.gov/phin/resources/vocabulary/index.html) which includes over 900 concepts for representing race and ethnicity of which 921 reference race.  The race concepts are grouped by and pre-mapped to the 5 OMB race categories:

   - American Indian or Alaska Native
   - Asian
   - Black or African American
   - Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander
   - White.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: race | FHIR Short: (USCDI) US Core Race Extension

   - White.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: race | FHIR Short: (USCDI) US Core Race Extension

column4: FHIR Definition: Concepts classifying the person into a named category of humans sharing common history, traits, geographical origin or nationality.  The ethnicity codes used to represent these concepts are based upon the [CDC ethnicity and Ethnicity Code Set Version 1.0](http://www.cdc.gov/phin/resources/vocabulary/index.html) which includes over 900 concepts for representing race and ethnicity of which 43 reference ethnicity.  The ethnicity concepts are grouped by and pre-mapped to the 2 OMB ethnicity categories: - Hispanic or Latino - Not Hispanic or Latino.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: ethnicity | FHIR Short: (USCDI) US Core ethnicity Extension

column15: Hispanic or Latino|Not Hispanic or Latino|asked but unknown|unknown

column4: FHIR Definition: A tribe or band with which a person associates whether or not they are an enrolled member.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: tribalAffiliation | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Tribal Affiliation Extension

column4: FHIR Definition: A code classifying the person's sex assigned at birth  as specified by the [Office of the National Coordinator for Health IT (ONC)](https://www.healthit.gov/newsroom/about-onc). | FHIR Comments: The codes required are intended to present birth sex (i.e., the sex recorded on the patient's birth certificate) and not gender identity or reassigned sex.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: birthsex | FHIR Short: Birth Sex Extension

column4: FHIR Definition: A code classifying the person's sex assigned at birth  as specified by the [Office of the National Coordinator for Health IT (ONC)](https://www.healthit.gov/newsroom/about-onc). | FHIR Comments: The codes required are intended to present birth sex (i.e., the sex recorded on the patient's birth certificate) and not gender identity or reassigned sex.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: birthsex | FHIR Short: Birth Sex Extension

column4: FHIR Definition: The US Core Sex Extension is used to reflect the documentation of a person's sex. It aligns with the C-CDA Sex Observation (LOINC 46098-0).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: sex | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Sex Extension

column4: FHIR Definition: The US Core Sex Extension is used to reflect the documentation of a person's sex. It aligns with the C-CDA Sex Observation (LOINC 46098-0).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: sex | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Sex Extension

column4: FHIR Definition: The US Core Sex Extension is used to reflect the documentation of a person's sex. It aligns with the C-CDA Sex Observation (LOINC 46098-0).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: sex | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Sex Extension

column4: FHIR Definition: An individual's personal sense of being a man, woman, boy, girl, nonbinary, or something else. | FHIR Comments: This represents an individual's identity, ascertained by asking them what that identity is.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: genderIdentity | FHIR Short: (USCDI) The individual's gender identity

column4: FHIR Definition: An individual's personal sense of being a man, woman, boy, girl, nonbinary, or something else. | FHIR Comments: This represents an individual's identity, ascertained by asking them what that identity is.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.extension | FHIR Slice Name: genderIdentity | FHIR Short: (USCDI) The individual's gender identity
column15: asked but unknown|other|Male-to-female transsexual (finding)|Female-to-male transsexual (finding)|Identifies as non-conforming gender (finding)|Identifies as female gender (finding)|Identifies as male gender (finding)

column4:
FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself). | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone. | FHIR Requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.modifierExtension | FHIR Short: Extensions that cannot be ignored

column4: FHIR Definition: An identifier for this patient. | FHIR Requirements: Patients are almost always assigned specific numerical identifiers.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) An identifier for this patient

column4: FHIR Definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.id | FHIR Short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

column4: FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.extension | FHIR Short: Additional content defined by implementations

column4: FHIR Definition: The purpose of this identifier. | FHIR Comments: Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary. | FHIR Requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.use | FHIR Short: usual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: required | FHIR Binding Description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose. | FHIR Comments: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type. | FHIR Requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.type | FHIR Short: Description of identifier
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: extensible | FHIR Binding Description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

column4: FHIR Definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique. | FHIR Comments: Identifier.system is always case sensitive. | FHIR Requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.system | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) The namespace for the identifier value

column4: FHIR Definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system. | FHIR Comments: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-rendered-value.html). Identifier.value is to be treated as case sensitive unless knowledge of the Identifier.system allows the processer to be confident that non-case-sensitive processing is safe.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.value | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) The value that is unique within the system.

column4: FHIR Definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.period | FHIR Short: Time period when id is/was valid for use

column4: FHIR Definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier. | FHIR Comments: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.identifier.assigner | FHIR Short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)

column4:
FHIR Definition: Whether this patient record is in active use.
Many systems use this property to mark as non-current patients, such as those that have not been seen for a period of time based on an organization's business rules.

It is often used to filter patient lists to exclude inactive patients

Deceased patients may also be marked as inactive for the same reasons, but may be active for some time after death. | FHIR Comments: If a record is inactive, and linked to an active record, then future patient/record updates should occur on the other patient. | FHIR Requirements: Need to be able to mark a patient record as not to be used because it was created in error. | FHIR Meaning When Missing: This resource is generally assumed to be active if no value is provided for the active element
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.active | FHIR Short: Whether this patient's record is in active use
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: A name associated with the individual. | FHIR Comments: A patient may have multiple names with different uses or applicable periods. For animals, the name is a "HumanName" in the sense that is assigned and used by humans and has the same patterns. | FHIR Requirements: Need to be able to track the patient by multiple names. Examples are your official name and a partner name.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) A name associated with the patient

column4: FHIR Definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.id | FHIR Short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

column4: FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.extension | FHIR Short: Additional content defined by implementations

column4: FHIR Definition: Identifies the purpose for this name. | FHIR Comments: Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old. | FHIR Requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.use | FHIR Short: (USCDI) usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: required | FHIR Binding Description: The use of a human name.
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: Specifies the entire name as it should be displayed e.g. on an application UI. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts. | FHIR Comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating a name SHALL ensure that when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part. | FHIR Requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.text | FHIR Short: Text representation of the full name

column4: FHIR Definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father. | FHIR Comments: Family Name may be decomposed into specific parts using extensions (de, nl, es related cultures).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.family | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Family name (often called 'Surname')

column4: FHIR Definition: Given name. | FHIR Comments: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name parts. Initials may be separated into multiple given names but often aren't due to paractical limitations.  This element is not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.given | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names

column4: FHIR Definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.prefix | FHIR Short: Parts that come before the name

column4: FHIR Definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.suffix | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Parts that come after the name

column4: FHIR Definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person. | FHIR Requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.name.period | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Time period when name was/is in use

column4: FHIR Definition: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the individual may be contacted. | FHIR Comments: A Patient may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods.  May need to have options for contacting the person urgently and also to help with identification. The address might not go directly to the individual, but may reach another party that is able to proxy for the patient (i.e. home phone, or pet owner's phone). | FHIR Requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom | FHIR Short: (USCDI) A contact detail for the individual

column4: FHIR Definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom.id | FHIR Short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

column4: FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom.extension | FHIR Short: Additional content defined by implementations

column4: FHIR Definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom.system | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) phone | fax | email | pager | url | sms | other
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: required | FHIR Binding Description: Telecommunications form for contact point.

column4: FHIR Definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address). | FHIR Comments: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value. | FHIR Requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom.value | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) The actual contact point details

column4: FHIR Definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point. | FHIR Comments: Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old. | FHIR Requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom.use | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. ContactPoints with lower rank values are more preferred than those with higher rank values. | FHIR Comments: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom.rank | FHIR Short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)

column4: FHIR Definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.telecom.period | FHIR Short: Time period when the contact point was/is in use

column4: FHIR Definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the patient is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes. | FHIR Comments: The gender might not match the biological sex as determined by genetics or the individual's preferred identification. Note that for both humans and particularly animals, there are other legitimate possibilities than male and female, though the vast majority of systems and contexts only support male and female.  Systems providing decision support or enforcing business rules should ideally do this on the basis of Observations dealing with the specific sex or gender aspect of interest (anatomical, chromosomal, social, etc.)  However, because these observations are infrequently recorded, defaulting to the administrative gender is common practice.  Where such defaulting occurs, rule enforcement should allow for the variation between administrative and biological, chromosomal and other gender aspects.  For example, an alert about a hysterectomy on a male should be handled as a warning or overridable error, not a "hard" error.  See the Patient Gender and Sex section for additional information about communicating patient gender and sex. | FHIR Requirements: Needed for identification of the individual, in combination with (at least) name and birth date.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.gender | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) male | female | other | unknown

column4: FHIR Definition: The date of birth for the individual. | FHIR Comments: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real DOB is unknown  There is a standard extension "patient-birthTime" available that should be used where Time is required (such as in maternity/infant care systems). | FHIR Requirements: Age of the individual drives many clinical processes.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.birthDate | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) The date of birth for the individual

column4: FHIR Definition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not. | FHIR Comments: If there's no value in the instance, it means there is no statement on whether or not the individual is deceased. Most systems will interpret the absence of a value as a sign of the person being alive. | FHIR Requirements: The fact that a patient is deceased influences the clinical process. Also, in human communication and relation management it is necessary to know whether the person is alive.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.deceased[x] | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Indicates if the individual is deceased or not
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: An address for the individual. | FHIR Comments: Patient may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods. | FHIR Requirements: May need to keep track of patient addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements and also to help with identification.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) An address for the individual

column4: FHIR Definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.id | FHIR Short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

column4: FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.extension | FHIR Short: Additional content defined by implementations

column4: FHIR Definition: The purpose of this address. | FHIR Comments: Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old. | FHIR Requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.use | FHIR Short: (USCDI) home | work | temp | old | billing - purpose of this address
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: required | FHIR Binding Description: The use of an address.
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: Distinguishes between physical addresses (those you can visit) and mailing addresses (e.g. PO Boxes and care-of addresses). Most addresses are both. | FHIR Comments: The definition of Address states that "address is intended to describe postal addresses, not physical locations". However, many applications track whether an address has a dual purpose of being a location that can be visited as well as being a valid delivery destination, and Postal addresses are often used as proxies for physical locations (also see the [Location](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/location.html#) resource).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.type | FHIR Short: postal | physical | both
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: required | FHIR Binding Description: The type of an address (physical / postal).

column4: FHIR Definition: Specifies the entire address as it should be displayed e.g. on a postal label. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts. | FHIR Comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating an address SHALL ensure that  when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part. | FHIR Requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.text | FHIR Short: Text representation of the address

column4: FHIR Definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.line | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc.

column4: FHIR Definition: The name of the city, town, suburb, village or other community or delivery center.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.city | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Name of city, town etc.

column4: FHIR Definition: The name of the administrative area (county). | FHIR Comments: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' is used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.district | FHIR Short: District name (aka county)

column4: FHIR Definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (e.g. US 2 letter state codes).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.state | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Sub-unit of country (abbreviations ok)
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: extensible | FHIR Binding Description: Two Letter USPS alphabetic codes.

column4: FHIR Definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.postalCode | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) US Zip Codes

column4: FHIR Definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted. | FHIR Comments: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a human readable country name.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.country | FHIR Short: Country (e.g. can be ISO 3166 2 or 3 letter code)

column4: FHIR Definition: Time period when address was/is in use. | FHIR Requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.address.period | FHIR Short: (USCDI) Time period when address was/is in use

column4: FHIR Definition: This field contains a patient's most recent marital (civil) status. | FHIR Requirements: Most, if not all systems capture it.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.maritalStatus | FHIR Short: Marital (civil) status of a patient
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: extensible | FHIR Binding Description: The domestic partnership status of a person.

column4: FHIR Definition: Indicates whether the patient is part of a multiple (boolean) or indicates the actual birth order (integer). | FHIR Comments: Where the valueInteger is provided, the number is the birth number in the sequence. E.g. The middle birth in triplets would be valueInteger=2 and the third born would have valueInteger=3 If a boolean value was provided for this triplets example, then all 3 patient records would have valueBoolean=true (the ordering is not indicated). | FHIR Requirements: For disambiguation of multiple-birth children, especially relevant where the care provider doesn't meet the patient, such as labs.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.multipleBirth[x] | FHIR Short: Whether patient is part of a multiple birth

column4:
FHIR Definition: Image of the patient. | FHIR Comments: Guidelines:
* Use id photos, not clinical photos.
* Limit dimensions to thumbnail.
* Keep byte count low to ease resource updates. | FHIR Requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of the patient. Fits with newer social media usage too.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.photo | FHIR Short: Image of the patient

column4: FHIR Definition: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient. | FHIR Comments: Contact covers all kinds of contact parties: family members, business contacts, guardians, caregivers. Not applicable to register pedigree and family ties beyond use of having contact. | FHIR Requirements: Need to track people you can contact about the patient.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact | FHIR Short: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient

column4: FHIR Definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.id | FHIR Short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

column4: FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.extension | FHIR Short: Additional content defined by implementations

column4:
FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself). | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone. | FHIR Requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.modifierExtension | FHIR Short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the contact person. | FHIR Requirements: Used to determine which contact person is the most relevant to approach, depending on circumstances.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.relationship | FHIR Short: The kind of relationship
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: extensible | FHIR Binding Description: The nature of the relationship between a patient and a contact person for that patient.

column4: FHIR Definition: A name associated with the contact person. | FHIR Requirements: Contact persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that contact person.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.name | FHIR Short: A name associated with the contact person

column4: FHIR Definition: A contact detail for the person, e.g. a telephone number or an email address. | FHIR Comments: Contact may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods.  May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification. | FHIR Requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.telecom | FHIR Short: A contact detail for the person

column4: FHIR Definition: Address for the contact person. | FHIR Requirements: Need to keep track where the contact person can be contacted per postal mail or visited.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.address | FHIR Short: Address for the contact person

column4: FHIR Definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the contact person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes. | FHIR Requirements: Needed to address the person correctly.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.gender | FHIR Short: male | female | other | unknown
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: required | FHIR Binding Description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes.

column4: FHIR Definition: Organization on behalf of which the contact is acting or for which the contact is working. | FHIR Requirements: For guardians or business related contacts, the organization is relevant.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.organization | FHIR Short: Organization that is associated with the contact

column4: FHIR Definition: The period during which this contact person or organization is valid to be contacted relating to this patient.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.contact.period | FHIR Short: The period during which this contact person or organization is valid to be contacted relating to this patient

column4: FHIR Definition: A language which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health. | FHIR Comments: If no language is specified, this *implies* that the default local language is spoken.  If you need to convey proficiency for multiple modes, then you need multiple Patient.Communication associations.   For animals, language is not a relevant field, and should be absent from the instance. If the Patient does not speak the default local language, then the Interpreter Required Standard can be used to explicitly declare that an interpreter is required. | FHIR Requirements: If a patient does not speak the local language, interpreters may be required, so languages spoken and proficiency are important things to keep track of both for patient and other persons of interest.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.communication | FHIR Short: (USCDI) A language which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health

column4: FHIR Definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.communication.id | FHIR Short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

column4: FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.communication.extension | FHIR Short: Additional content defined by implementations

column4:
FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself). | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone. | FHIR Requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.communication.modifierExtension | FHIR Short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: The ISO-639-1 alpha 2 code in lower case for the language, optionally followed by a hyphen and the ISO-3166-1 alpha 2 code for the region in upper case; e.g. "en" for English, or "en-US" for American English versus "en-EN" for England English. | FHIR Comments: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type. | FHIR Requirements: Most systems in multilingual countries will want to convey language. Not all systems actually need the regional dialect.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.communication.language | FHIR Must Support?: Y | FHIR Short: (USCDI) The language which can be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health

column4: FHIR Definition: Indicates whether or not the patient prefers this language (over other languages he masters up a certain level). | FHIR Comments: This language is specifically identified for communicating healthcare information. | FHIR Requirements: People that master multiple languages up to certain level may prefer one or more, i.e. feel more confident in communicating in a particular language making other languages sort of a fall back method.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.communication.preferred | FHIR Short: Language preference indicator

column4:
FHIR Definition: Patient's nominated care provider. | FHIR Comments: This may be the primary care provider (in a GP context), or it may be a patient nominated care manager in a community/disability setting, or even organization that will provide people to perform the care provider roles.  It is not to be used to record Care Teams, these should be in a CareTeam resource that may be linked to the CarePlan or EpisodeOfCare resources.
Multiple GPs may be recorded against the patient for various reasons, such as a student that has his home GP listed along with the GP at university during the school semesters, or a "fly-in/fly-out" worker that has the onsite GP also included with his home GP to remain aware of medical issues.

Jurisdictions may decide that they can profile this down to 1 if desired, or 1 per type.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.generalPractitioner | FHIR Short: Patient's nominated primary care provider

column4: FHIR Definition: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record. | FHIR Comments: There is only one managing organization for a specific patient record. Other organizations will have their own Patient record, and may use the Link property to join the records together (or a Person resource which can include confidence ratings for the association). | FHIR Requirements: Need to know who recognizes this patient record, manages and updates it.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.managingOrganization | FHIR Short: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record

column4:
FHIR Definition: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual patient. | FHIR Comments: There is no assumption that linked patient records have mutual links. | FHIR Requirements: There are multiple use cases:

* Duplicate patient records due to the clerical errors associated with the difficulties of identifying humans consistently, and
* Distribution of patient information across multiple servers.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.link | FHIR Short: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.link.id | FHIR Short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

column4: FHIR Definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.link.extension | FHIR Short: Additional content defined by implementations

column4:

Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself). | FHIR Comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone. | FHIR Requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.link.modifierExtension | FHIR Short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
column22: FHIR Is Modifier?: Y | FHIR Is Summary?: Y

column4: FHIR Definition: The other patient resource that the link refers to. | FHIR Comments: Referencing a RelatedPerson here removes the need to use a Person record to associate a Patient and RelatedPerson as the same individual.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.link.other | FHIR Short: The other patient or related person resource that the link refers to

column4: FHIR Definition: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.
column5: FHIR Path: Patient.link.type | FHIR Short: replaced-by | replaces | refer | seealso
column21: FHIR Binding Strength: required | FHIR Binding Description: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.
